gray city attorney ____________ margaret drewniak city clerktreasurer preface this a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the city of whiting indiana source materials used in the preparation of the the 1979 as supplemented no 142 199 and ordinances subsequently adopted by the common council the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1979 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included in the same manner if the new material is to be included between chapters 12 and 13 it will be designated as chapter 125 care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 code index cdi1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of milton e lefkoff supervising editor of the municipal tallahassee florida credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publishers staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project the publisher is most grateful to mr donald gray city attorney ms margaret drewniak city clerktreasurer honorable rudy wunder councilperson and honorable bill ciesar jr councilperson for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication it is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the daytoday administration of the citys and not included in the recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance unless another penalty is expressly provided every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the any ordinance rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $250000 each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense the penalty provided by this section unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance in addition to the penalty prescribed above the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits additions or general provisions how cited the ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the ordinances city of whiting indiana and may be so cited state law reference codification of ordinances ic 36151 et seq rules of construction and definitions in the construction of this of all ordinances the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the common council the rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto generally all general provisions terms phrases and expressions contained in this be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the common council may be fully carried out in the interpretation and application of any provisions of this they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health safety comfort convenience and general welfare where any provision of the greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision imposed by the other law the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling city the word city shall mean the city of whiting indiana this code the terms  or this  shall mean the ordinances city of whiting indiana as designated in section 11 common council council whenever the term council or common council is used it shall be construed to mean the common council of the city of whiting computation of time the time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last if the last day is sunday it shall be excluded and the next day shall be included corporate limits city limits the term corporate limits or city limits shall mean the legal boundaries of the city of whiting except as otherwise provided by law county the words the county or this county shall mean the county of lake in the state of indiana delegation of authority whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or perform some duty it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise gender a word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms partnerships and corporations as well as to males ic the letters ic refer to the cited provision of the indiana as now or hereafter amended joint authority all words giving joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers jurisdiction except as specifically provided otherwise the provisions of the be interpreted to apply only within the corporate limits law the word law shall mean any applicable statute ordinance rule or regulation promulgated by the city or any agency thereof the state or any agency thereof the united states or any agency thereof or any body politic and corporate or agency thereof may the word may is permissive month the word month shall mean a calendar month nontechnical and technical words words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning number a word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person or thing and a word importing the plural may extend to the singular oath the word oath shall be construed to include any affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed officers etc whenever any officer department board or commission is referred to by title such as clerktreasurer such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words of the city of whiting orand the word or may be read and and and may be read or if the sense requires it owner the word owner applied to a building or land shall include any part owner joint owner tenant in common tenant in partnership joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land person the word person shall extend and be applied to associations clubs societies organizations firms companies partnerships bodies politic and corporate or any other group as well as to natural persons personal property the term personal property includes every species of property except real property as herein described preceding following the words preceding and following mean next before and next after respectively property the word property shall include real and personal property public place the term public place shall mean any street or highway sidewalk park cemetery schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto and any lake or stream quorum the word quorum shall mean a majority of the members of a board commission or committee holding office unless otherwise specifically provided in this property the term real property shall include lands tenements and hereditaments reasonable time reasonable notice in all cases where any provision shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given to any person such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary in the prompt execution of such duty or compliance with such notice shall the word shall is mandatory sidewalk the word sidewalk shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians excluding parkways signature subscription the word signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write state the words the state or this state shall be construed to mean the state of indiana street the word street shall be construed to embrace streets avenues boulevards roads alleys viaducts and all other public highways in the city tenant occupant the word tenant or occupant applied to a building or land shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land either alone or with others tense words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present written in writing the term written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words letters or figures whether by printing or otherwise year the word year shall mean a calendar year certain ordinances not affected by in this the ordinance adopting this affect any ordinance 1 promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the citys indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city  2 granting any right or franchise  3 dedicating naming establishing locating relocating opening paving widening vacating etc any street or public way in the city  4 making any appropriation  5 establishing or prescribing grades in the city  6 providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor  7 dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or otherwise relating to subdivisions  8 extending or contracting the boundaries of the city  9 prescribing ordinances a when any ordinance repealing a former ordinance clause or provision shall be itself repealed such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided b the repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect nor any suit prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed severability of parts of sections paragraphs sentences clauses and phrases of this severable other applications thereof general penalty except as otherwise provided by state law wherever in this or in any ordinance of the city or rule or regulation promulgated by an officer or agency thereof under the authority invested by law or ordinance any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful of an offense or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense where no specific penalty is provided therefore the violation of any such provision of the ordinance rule or regulation is hereby declared to be an offense and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $250000 for a first offense and a fine not to exceed $750000 for a second or subsequent offense unless the violation is of an ordinance that regulates traffic or parking in such cases the fine may not exceed the sum of $250000 every day a violation of this any such ordinance rule or regulation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense in any prosecution based upon this section it shall be necessary to allege only the first day with respect to which any forfeiture is assessable and upon conviction the offender shall be assessed for that day and each day subsequent thereto with respect to which it is proven and found that the person did commit such violation  7506 state law reference limitations on penalties ic 36138810 offenses 36467 order of business the following shall be the order of business in meetings of the common council 1 roll call of councilpersons 2 reading correction and approval of the minutes of the previous meeting 3 reading of communications petitions memorials and remonstrances 4 report of the mayor 5 report of standing committees 6 report of the city clerktreasurer 7 report of the city attorney 8 report of special committees 9 unfinished business 10 reading of ordinances and resolutions 11 new business 12 open discussion public 13 adjournment   part 1989 rules of procedure a a majority of all the elected members shall constitute a quorum b all citizens other than the mayor and members of the council desiring to address the mayor or the council collectively or individually must stand state their name and address and must be recognized by the mayor before being permitted to speak and shall be permitted to speak c written copies of all resolutions and ordinances to be presented for adoption or passage at any meeting of the council must be presented to the mayor councilpersons and the clerktreasurer at least three days in advance of the meeting at which such resolution or ordinance is to be presented for adoption or passage receipt of such documents shall be presumed upon showing delivery to the respective residences of each of such persons at least three days in advance of the meeting by one of the following methods 1 a personal delivery of such documents as shown by a receipt signed by such person or a member of his immediate family acknowledging the reception of such documents 2 mailing such documents by either certified mail or registered mail return receipt requested to the usual residence of each councilperson with sufficient postage affixed thereon 3 personal delivery of such documents by any city officer or official at the usual residence of the councilperson   part 1989 state law reference quorum ic 364610 method of voting the vote upon any motion before the council shall be by aye and no voice votes except in the case of a third and final passage of an ordinance in which case the vote shall be by roll call vote or if an elected member of the council shall request a roll call vote in which case the vote shall also be by roll call vote the presiding officer shall have the power to determine the outcome of a voice vote  however any elected member of the council may challenge that decision and request a roll call vote to verify or overrule the presiding officers decision in the event of a tie roll call vote the presiding officer shall have the power to break the tie vote    1989 state law reference majority vote and twothirds vote defined ic 364611 committees all duly elected members of the city council shall serve respectively in both capacities as members of the finance and ordinance committees these committees shall then select a chairman from the membership of their committee the mayor may select other committees as necessity dictates any ordinance referred to committee may be called from committee for action on the council floor by the committee chairman or by a majority vote of the elected members of the common council    1989 resolutions all resolutions may be passed and adopted upon motion by a majority vote such resolutions may be adopted by a title only reading    1989 ordinances a all ordinances shall be passed and adopted in the manner following 1 each ordinance shall receive three separate readings by title only prior to its passage 2 such ordinance shall be passed from first to second reading by a majority vote of all elected members present such ordinance shall be passed from second to third reading and thereby made effective by majority vote of all elected members present 3 any council member may request that an ordinance under consideration be read in its entirety as opposed to a title only reading b a twothirds vote of all the elected members after unanimous consent of the members present to consider the ordinance is required to pass an ordinance of the council on the same day or at the same meeting at which it is introduced this subsection does not apply to a zoning ordinance or amendment to a zoning ordinance that is adopted under ic 367    1989 state law reference passage of ordinance ic 364612 et seq presiding officer may limit debate the presiding officer shall allow meaningful and orderly discussion by any member or citizen and may not arbitrarily place a time limit on that discussion debate should be orderly and to the point the presiding officer shall have the responsibility of conducting the discussions and debates in an orderly manner and limitations thereon shall be at the discretion of the presiding officer    1989 state law reference presiding officer ic 36468 expulsion of members or persons at meetings the mayor or presiding officer shall maintain order throughout any and all meetings of the common council and shall order the expulsion from the council chamber of any member whom he shall deem disorderly and obstructing the administration of municipal affairs he shall likewise order the expulsion from the council chamber of any other person who in any manner interferes with the conduct of the business before the common council    1989 reports of committees all standing council committees shall give reports at regular meetings of the common council each committee report shall be given by that committees chairman or his designated representative    1989 city clerktreasurer report the city clerktreasurer shall submit such reports to the common council as may be requested by the common council for its information and advice    1989 state law reference city clerk ic 36469 ordinances resolutions filed with city clerktreasurer all ordinances and resolutions shall be filed with the city clerktreasurer in duplicate the original of which shall not be taken from the office of the clerktreasurer    1989 misconduct of city official  impeachment all charges of misconduct against any city official or employee shall be reduced to writing and sworn to by the complainant who shall file such complaint with the city clerktreasurer the clerktreasurer shall file such complaint with the mayor who shall appoint a committee to investigate the charges and who shall report back in writing their findings signed by each member of the committee the report of such committee shall then be read before the common council for its approval or rejection if the findings of such committee is approved by the common council against an officer or employee of the city the council shall then proceed to vote on the punishment which it may deem sufficient for the misconduct complained of but in no event shall the punishment exceed removal from office provided however that such investigating committee shall give notice to the complainant and to the officer or employee complained of at the time and place when and where it will meet to hear evidence in the cause and provided further that any officer or employee so complained of and against whom the investigating committee shall have found may petition the common council for a hearing before the common council as a whole which petition shall be granted as a matter of right without any action upon the part of the common council thereupon the common council shall fix a time and place where and when it will hear the complainant and the officer or employee complained against and shall at such time and place make its finding and assess the punishment as hereinbefore provided the finding and punishment assessed by the common council shall be final and conclusive against all officers and employees of the city    1989 state law reference expulsion of members ic 36466 manner of roll call votes whenever a roll call vote is called for upon any motion resolution or ordinance each member shall when his name is called on the roll vote either in the affirmative or negative if any member of the common council fails refuses or abstains on a vote or leaves the council chamber so as to avoid voting on the motion resolution or ordinance the clerktreasurer shall record the vote of such member as being with the majority vote    1989 special council meeting a special meeting of the common council may be called by the mayor or upon the call of a majority of the elected members of the common council a record shall be kept of such special meeting and such record must show a quorum present and must record the events and actions which occur at such special meetings the record shall be read approved or corrected and approved as corrected at the next regular meeting of the common council items to be considered by the common council at such special meetings should be determined prior to the meeting however upon suspension of the rules by the required twothirds vote the common council may consider any item at such special meetings    1989 state law reference meetings ic 36467 roberts rules of order adopted of roberts rules of order such as is not in conflict with any of the rules in this division is hereby made a part hereof applicants  qualifications and requirements  probationary period a citizenship an applicant for a position of any kind for the police department must be a citizen of the united states of america and an elector of the county in which the applicant resides and who can read and write the english language an applicant must be a high school graduate or have an equivalent education to be determined by examination designated by the board of public safety b intelligence quotient an applicant shall have a minimum intelligence quotient as designated by the board of public safety from time to time c character  fitness an applicant for a position of any kind for the police department must meet the following qualifications 1 the applicant must be at least 21 years of age and not more than 35 years of age the minimum age requirement shall be interpreted to include those applicants who will attain the minimum age requirement within 60 days subsequent to filing an application and the maximum age requirement shall be interpreted to include those applicants that are not older than the indicated age at the time of the appointment 2 the applicant must meet the physical and mental requirements of the board of public safety and the pension board 3 the applicant must be of good moral character d applications all applications for the police department shall be executed under oath and in triplicate  one copy of the application shall be submitted to the board of trustees of the police pension fund at the time of the application one copy shall be submitted to the board of public safety and one copy shall be retained in the files of the police chief e probation every appointment to the police department shall be for a probationary period of one year if at any time during the probationary period the conduct or capacity of the probationer is found not to be satisfactory which fact shall be determined by the board of public safety upon the recommendation for discharge by the police chief the probationer shall without hearing and without right of appeal be notified in writing by the board of public safety that the applicant will not receive an appointment as a fulltime police officer whereupon employment shall cease  otherwise retention in service after the expiration of the probationary period shall be equivalent to and shall constitute final appointment as a fulltime police officer      2 122992 state law reference residence required ic 36842  probationary appointments ic 368412 dismissals and suspensions a policemen who have been appointed as full time the city clerktreasurer the obligation to bargain in good faith shall include the duty to cause any agreement resulting from such negotiations to be reduced to writing the respective parties shall meet at least on three occasions after the initial notice to bargain referred to in this section and in section 2317 and all parties shall bargain in good faith on any and all issues c nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prevent the parties from entering into an agreement covering a period of more than one calendar year  4 42093 representatives the spokespersons and representatives for the board of public works and safety shall be the mayor andor two of his designees the spokespersons for the common council shall be three members selected by the common council the fraternal order of police lodge no 68 and firefighters local no 969 shall select six persons to represent their interest three being from each bargaining unit the fraternal order of police lodge no 68 and firefighters local no 969 shall have the option of bargaining separate from each other if they so desire each of the parties may obtain appropriate legal representation during any collective bargaining procedure  5 42093 exclusive mechanism this division provides the exclusive mechanism by which the city the fraternal order of police lodge no 68 and firefighters local no 969 shall carry out collective bargaining the city shall not be required to deal directly with the individuals in the bargaining unit in lieu of bargaining collectively the fraternal order of police lodge no 68 and the employees of the bargaining unit shall not attempt to deal directly with any representatives of the city other than those identified in this division such an attempt shall be deemed an act of bad faith bargaining the whiting firefighters local no 969 and the employees of the bargaining unit shall not attempt to deal directly with any representatives of the city other than those identified in this division such an attempt shall be deemed an act of bad faith bargaining  6 42093 impasse and advisory mediation a if the bargaining agents and the city are unable within 60 days from and after the date of the first meeting to develop a collective bargaining agreement either party may declare that an impasse has been reached and request advisory mediation the federal mediation and conciliation service shall within 14 days from the date of request for mediation promptly assign as soon as possible a mediator if either party refuses to engage in the mediation process then the party that refuses to engage shall bear any cost incurred by the party requesting mediation if the parties engage in the mediation all costs shall be shared onehalf by the city and onehalf by the fraternal order of police lodge no 68 andor firefighters local no 969 the recommendation and action of the mediator shall be advisory only and shall have no binding authority or effect on any of the parties b the parties may mutually agree to any other method of selecting an advisory mediator provided such method is likely to result in the selection of an impartial and knowledgeable mediator c the hearing conducted by the mediator shall be concluded within 20 days from the commencement and within ten days after the conclusion of this meeting the mediator shall make written findings and conclusions on the issues prescribed a copy of which is to be mailed or otherwise delivered to the bargaining units and the city the mediators decision shall be considered nonbinding unless the bargaining units and the city and common council agree prior to mediation that the decisions in certain areas shall be binding upon the parties decisions in regard to annual pay and monetary fringe benefits and hours of employment shall be subject to approval by the common council and in accordance with the requirements of ic 36833  7 42093 strikes work stoppages slowdowns and other changes prohibited a the fraternal order of with or departures from the performance of duties as prescribed by the city the bargaining units shall not engage in encourage sanction or defend any such activities against the city b if any of the activities referred to in this section take place in addition to other appropriate remedies undertaken by the city pursuant to this division any collective bargaining agreement entered into between the parties pursuant to this division shall be null and void and of no effect  provided however that any activity referred to in this section and done by either bargaining agent shall not affect the collective bargaining agreement of the other bargaining agent  8 42093 general law a this division shall not be deemed in any way to limit or diminish the authority and responsibility of the city to terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning controlled substance means any substance which an individual may or may not see possess use or distribute under the laws of the federal government or the state in which the individual is employed or working department director means the department head of the department intoxicant means an alcoholic beverage otherwise legal but illicitly used substance includes prescription drugs and overthecounter drugs not being used for their intended purposes  bd 12793 cross reference definitions generally  12 procedures  regulations a employees are expected to report to work on time and in appropriate mental and physical condition for work employees are not to report to work under the influence of intoxicants illegal drugs or illicitly used substances and shall not consume use or possess intoxicants illegal drugs or illicitly used substances at any time during their scheduled workday on city property or in any city vehicle while traveling to or from city property while on duty the unlawful manufacture distribution dispensation possession or use of a controlled substance intoxicant or illicitly used substance on city premises or while conducting city business off premises is absolutely prohibited violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination and may have legal consequences b if a supervisor has reasonable cause to believe that an employee has reported to work under the influence of intoxicants illegal drugs or illicitly used substances the supervisor with the approval of the department director has the right to request that the employee submit to an alcohol or drug screening test at the citys expense for the purposes of this division random or routine drug testing shall not be conducted by the city and testing shall not be conducted in an arbitrary or discriminatory way toward any employee a supervisor must have reasonable cause for ordering an alcohol or drug screening test and shall document such reasonable cause the failure of an employee to submit to an alcohol or drug screening test shall be grounds for discipline which may include termination the results of the alcohol or drug test shall not be used by the city for any purpose other than to determine adherence to city policy to discipline an employee whenever necessary and to comply with applicable terms of this division c the city recognizes drug dependency as a major problem the city also recognizes drug abuse as a potential health safety and security problem when it is determined that an employee is suffering from a drug or alcohol abuse problem reasonable efforts by the city may be made to rehabilitate the employee using available community resources however this does not foreclose the right to administer discipline up to and including discharge conscientious efforts to seek such help will not jeopardize any employees job and will not be noted in any personnel record except where action follows a supervisoryinitiated referral the city is committed to assisting employees in this endeavor in any way possible d no employee shall be subject to discipline for the appropriate use of legal nonprescription or prescribed legal drugs for the treatment of illness or injury however if the employee knows or should know that use of a nonprescription or prescribed drug does or could impair the employees ability to operate a city vehicle or equipment or otherwise perform his job duties the employee shall share this information with his immediate supervisor a violation of this section may subject the employee to disciplinary action e employees must as a condition of employment abide by the terms of this division and report any conviction under a criminal drug statute for violations occurring on or off city premises while conducting city business a report of a conviction must be made within five days after the conviction to the department director within ten days of learning of an employees criminal conviction for illegal drug activity within the workplace the city will notify the federal government of such conviction within 30 days of learning of an employees criminal conviction for illegal drug activity within the workplace the city will take appropriate personnel action this requirement is mandated by the federally legislated drug free workplace act of 1988 f a copy of this division shall be vicious animals a applicability along with all other provisions of this chapter this section shall also apply to vicious animals and potentially vicious animals as defined in section 31 b determination of a potential vicious animal 1 after an investigation which must be initiated within three days after the situation becomes known to the animal control officer or hisher designee the animal control officer or hisher designee is authorized to make a determination whether an animal is potentially vicious based upon the faction listed in the definition of a potentially vicious animal in writing by certified mail or hand delivery with signature of that status within five days after the completion of the investigation 2 following written notice to the owner if the animal control officer or hisher designee has probably cause to believe that an animal is a potentially vicious animal and may pose a threat to public safety said officer or designee may issue an order to impound andor quarantine said animal pending disposition of the case or until the owner has fulfilled the requirements contained herein the owner of the animal may be liable to the city for the costs and expenses of keeping the animal 3 upon notice the owner may within seven calendar days after a determination that an animal is a potentially vicious animal appeal the determination to the board of public works and safety said appeal shall be in writing the board shall conduct a hearing into the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting the board may affirm the determination modify the determination or reverse the determination a decision by the board reversing the determination shall not affect the animal control officer or hisher designees right to later declare an animal to be a potentially vicious animal or a vicious animal or to determine that the animal poses a threat to public safety for the animals subsequent behavior c determination of a vicious animal 1 after an investigation which must be initiated within three days after the situation becomes known to the animal control officer the officer or hisher designee is authorized to make a determination whether an animal is vicious based on the factors listed above and shall notify the owner of the animal in writing by certified mail or hand delivery with signature of that status within five days after completing the investigation 2 following notice to the owner if the officer or hisher designee has probably cause and believes the animal to be a vicious animal and that the animal poses an imminent threat to public safety said officer or designee may issue an order for the immediate impoundment andor quarantine of said animal pending disposition of the case or until the animal owner has fulfilled the requirements contained herein the owner of the animal shall be liable to the city for the costs and expenses of keeping the animal if the animal is determined to be a vicious animal 3 the owner may within seven calendar days after a determination that an animal is a vicious animal appeal the determination to the board of public works and safety 4 said appeal shall be in writing the board shall conduct a hearing into the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting the board may affirm the determination modify the determination or reverse the determination a decision by the board reversing the determination shall not affect the animal control officer or hisher designees right to later declare an animal to be a potentially vicious animal or a vicious animal or to determine that the animal poses a threat to public safety for the animals subsequent behavior d exceptions no animal shall be declared a vicious or potentially vicious animal if 1 the animal was used by a law enforcement official for legitimate law enforcement purposes  2 the threat injury or damage was sustained by a person a who was committing at the time a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises lawfully occupied by the owner of the animal  b who was provoking tormenting abusing or assaulting the animal or who can be shown to have repeatedly in the past provoked tormented abused or assaulted the animal  or c who was committing or attempting to commit a crime  or 3 the animal was a responding to pain or injury or was protecting itself or its offspring  or b protecting or defending a human being within the immediate vicinity of the animal from an attack or assault e consequences of a vicious or potential vicious animal determination 1 if the animal control officer or hisher designee determines that an animal is a potentially vicious animal under subsection b above the owner shall comply with all of the provisions of this section and any other special security or care requirements said officer or designee may establish 2 if the animal control officer or hisher designee determines that an animal is a vicious animal under subsection c the owner shall comply with all of the provisions of this section and any other special security or care requirements said officer or designee may establish 3 the animal control officer or hisher designee may require impoundment andor quarantine of the animal until the owner of the animal has satisfied all the requirements of the certificate or registration holding permit the requirements must be met within 30 days if after 30 days the owner has not satisfied all the requirements of the holding permit the animal may be humanely destroyed on the 31st day f vicious animal and potentially vicious animal registration and handling requirements 1 the animal control officer or hisher designee shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a potentially vicious animal if the owner establishes to the satisfaction of said officer or designee all of the following a the owner of the potentially vicious animal is 21 years of age or older  b a valid animal license has been issued by the city of whiting  c the owner has proof of current rabies vaccination  d the owner has a proper enclosure to prevent the entry of any person or animal and the escape of said potentially vicious animal as described in subsection a  e the owner has paid the annual fee pursuant to the city of whiting fee schedule in addition to regular licensing fees to register the potentially vicious animal  f the potentially vicious animal has been spayed or neutered  g the potentially vicious animal has been implanted with a microchip containing owner identification information and said information is registered with the city  h the owner shall enter the animal in a socialization behavior program approved by the city 2 the animal control officer or hisher designee shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a vicious animal if the owner in addition to satisfying the requirements for registration of a potentially vicious animal pursuant to paragraph 1 above establishes to the satisfaction of said officer or hisher designee all of the following a the owner of the vicious animal has written permission of the property owner or homeowners association if applicable where the vicious animal will be kept  b the owner will maintain the vicious animal exclusively on the owners property except for medical treatment or examination  and c the owner of the vicious animal has posted on the premises a clearly visible written warning sign that there is a vicious animal on the property with a conspicuous warning symbol that informs children of the presence of a vicious animal the sign shall be very visible from the public roadway or 50 feet whichever is less 3 the officer of hisher designee may order the immediate impoundment or humane destruction of a vicious animal if the owner fails to abide by the conditions for registration or confinement or handling of a vicious animal 4 if any animal previously determined to be a potentially vicious animal has not exhibited any of the behaviors specified in subsection a1a within the 36 months since the date of the potentially vicious animal determination then that animal is eligible for a review of the determination with the potential for lifting the requirements of this section  provided however that that same animal may again be declared a vicious or potentially vicious animal if it again exhibits any of the specified behaviors g vicious or potentially vicious animal owner responsibility it shall be unlawful to 1 keep an animal determined to be vicious or potentially vicious without a valid certificate of registration issued under subsection f  2 permit a potentially vicious animal to be outside a proper enclosure unless the potentially vicious animal is under the control of a responsible person as defined in subsection a1b muzzled and restrained by a lead not exceeding four feet in length the muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any human being or animal  3 fail to maintain a vicious animal exclusively on the owners property as required except for medical treatment or examination when removed from the owners property for said reason the vicious animal shall be caged or under the control of a responsible person as defined herein muzzled and restrained with a lead not exceeding four feet in length the muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any human being or animal  4 fail to notify the animal control officer or the police department immediately upon escape if a vicious or potentially vicious animal is on the loose is unconfined or has attacked a human being within five calendar days if the animal has died or within 24 hours if the animal has been sold or has been given away if the vicious or potentially vicious animal has been sold or given away the owner shall provide the animal control officer or hisher designee with the name address and telephone number of the new owner  5 fail to surrender a vicious or potentially vicious animal to the animal control officer or hisher designee for safe confinement pending a disposition of the case when there is a reason to believe that the vicious or potentially vicious animal poses an imminent threat to public safety  or 6 fail to comply with any special security or care requirements for a vicious or potentially vicious animal which the officer or hisher designee may have established pursuant to the finding that the animal was potentially vicious or vicious iii 91307 feeding of nondomesticated animals prohibited no person shall feed or put out food stuff of any kind for any nondomesticated animal within the whiting city limits nondomesticated animal includes but is not limited to any animal which meets the definition of wild animal in wmc  31 seagulls pigeons squirrels geese ducks and other waterfowl this prohibition does not apply to the feeding of family pets or to bird feeders placed on private property this section shall be enforced by any duly authorized police officer of the city andor article shall expire at the end of each calendar year december 31 and shall be renewed annually upon payment of the required renewal fees as a matter of right if the applicant for renewal has not the required renewal fee the board or its designee upon the receipt of the application for renewal and the required renewal fee shall issue the license in the category the applicant has previously division 1  generally improper maintenance generally a any owner tenant or resident who fails to maintain a house building structure or real estate shall be in violation of this the lack of maintenance results in any of the following 1 structural deterioration rendering the house building or structure unsafe 2 unsafe or unhealthy condition of public utilities used in connection with the house building or structure 3 the existence of any condition conductive to the propagation of illness or disease 4 a gross and notorious state of general disrepair or dilapidation or an imminent hazard to the public health safety and welfare such that a blight on the neighborhood exists causing economic devaluation of surrounding properties b the failure to properly maintain a house building structure or real estate as the same set forth in subsection a of this section shall be deemed a public nuisance an owner tenant or resident found responsible for such violation shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $250000  each day of violation shall be deemed a separate offense c the building commissioner shall be empowered to maintain an action in court for the abatement of the nuisance and the recovery of all costs and expenses of the action including reasonable attorney fees  3 5493 secs 41774190  reserved division 2  property maintenance code definitions the following words terms and neglect lack of maintenance or excessive use exposed to public view refers to any premises or any part thereof or any building or any part thereof which may be lawfully viewed by the public exterior of the premises means open space on the premises outside of any building thereon extermination means the control and elimination of insects rodents and vermin or other pests on the premises which constitute a health hazard foundation means that portion of the building or structure generally below ground which supports the upper portions of the building or structure garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling preparation cooking and consumption of food habitable rooms means rooms used or designed for use by one or more persons for living or sleeping or cooking and eating but not including bathrooms water closet compartments laundries serving and storage pantries corridors foyers vestibules cellars heater rooms boiler rooms utility rooms and other rooms or spaces that are not used frequently or for an extended period of time or that have less than 50 square feet of superficial floor area shall not be considered habitable rooms infestation means the longterm or extended presence of insects rodents vermin or other pests on the premises which constitute a health hazard mixed occupancy means any building containing one or more dwelling units or rooming units and also having a portion thereof containing a permitted nonresidential use nuisance means 1 residential and nonresidential properties which by lack of maintenance and because of progressive deterioration have the effect of creating blighted areas a a blighted area may be either improved or vacant property within the territorial limits of the city b in evaluating whether a particular property is blighted the presence of one or more of the following factors can be used to support the conclusion that the particular property in question is blighted property however the factors should be viewed in totality of all the facts and circumstances as they relate to the property in question and must be present to such an extent that a reasonable person would conclude that public intervention is appropriate or necessary those factors supporting conclusion of blight include 1 age 2 dilapidation 3 obsolescence 4 illegal use of individual structures 5 presence of structures below minimum code standards 6 excessive vacancies 7 overcrowding of structures and community facilities 8 lack of ventilation light or sanitary facilities 9 inadequate utilities 10 the premises and all structures thereon shall be kept free of all nuisances and any hazards to the safety of the occupants pedestrians and other persons utilizing the premises and free of unsanitary conditions any of the foregoing shall be promptly removed and abated by the owner or operator b it shall be the duty of the owner or operator to keep the premises free of hazards which include but are not limited to the following 1 refuse brush weeds broken glass stumps roots obnoxious vegetation and growth filth garbage trash and debris 2 natural growth dead and dying trees and limbs or other natural growth which by reason of rotting or deteriorating conditions or storm damage constitute a hazard to persons in the vicinity thereof trees shall be kept properly pruned and trimmed to prevent such conditions topping shall not be an acceptable form of trimming existing ordinances of the city dealing with trees their maintenance removal and all other aspects of their care shall apply for purposes of this division 3 ground surface hazards or unsanitary conditions holes excavations breaks projections obstructions icy conditions uncleared snow and excretion of pets and other animals on paths walks driveways parking lots and parking areas and other parts of the premises which are accessible to holes and excavations shall be filled repaired or kept clear of all ground surface hazards 4 recurring accumulations of stormwater adequate stormwater runoff drains shall be provided and maintained to eliminate any recurrent or excessive accumulation of stormwater on the premises 5 areas of infestation and its source 6 foundation deterioration 2 foundations a foundations shall be kept structurally sound and shall be free of critical and major defects foundation walls shall 1 support the loads placed on them without indications of settlement bulge or buckle 2 prevent the entrance of water or excess moisture into the basement or crawl spaces cracks or holes in the wall or rotting of the wall which prevent the proper function of the foundation are considered faults for purposes of this division individual footings under exterior or interior columns should support the loads placed on them without indications of differential settlement b examples of critical and major foundation defects include 1 settlement to a degree that structural components supported by the foundation are detrimentally affected large cracks sagging walls outofplumb corners vertical separations of cracking and sloping floors are often indicators of a settling foundation 2 extreme crumbling failure of mortar joints or other deterioration such as that caused by heaving or buckling that would require replacement of the foundation 3 lack of adequate foundation support in a permanent building 4 other than concrete or masonry foundation in a permanent structure 5 foundation wall thickness less than that of wall supported 6 crack penetrating encompasses the entire thickness of foundation wall and extending from its top to base  cracks of this nature will be visible from both exterior and interior 7 multiple or numerous cracks not penetrating entire thickness of the foundation wall 8 foundation wall not extending above grade 9 flaking or deteriorating mortar over large areas of a stone foundation wall 10 excessive leakage or seepage foundation wall 11 numerous holes and loose material over large area of foundation wall 12 failure of the bearing capacity of the soil   insufficient original loadbearing capacity 3 loadbearing walls a the loadbearing walls and columns which support the structural loads between the floor and roof systems shall provide such support without bulging or buckling and shall be kept free of critical and major defects loadbearing walls shall provide such support without indications of settlement bulging or buckling and be maintained in a manner which will protect the surface from deterioration caused by the elements and should prevent the entrance of moisture and cold air into the building  for example in the foundation cracks or holes in the wall rotting of wall members or leaks which prevent the proper functioning of this component are faults b there are two types of loadbearing walls exterior masonry and exterior frame each of which has several defects peculiar to it 1 exterior masonry wall the same general types of failure and deteriorations as are observed in foundations in many instances the exterior wall exhibits diagonal cracking in addition to vertical and horizontal cracking such cracks generally are not confined to mortar joints themselves but tend to pass primary wall material as well as lintels over openings in the wall lack of watertightness or inadequate ventilation can cause rotting of sills toeplates etc an additional item of deterioration in masonry materials and concrete is the extensive chipping flaking crumbling and erosion of primary exterior wall material such deterioration in the exterior wall will lead to deterioration of the core of the wall which may result in failure of the wall if not corrected 2 exterior frame wall in wood walls lack of corner bracing disposal or ridged sheathing or firestops as well as the separation of joints or crushing of the ends of framing members can cause failure of the wall the entrance of moisture can cause rot which in turn can lead to failure of the wall for example rotting of toeplates sills studs bracing etc 3 examples of critical and major loadbearing wall defects include i walls which are severely out of plumb ii severe sagging over a large area iii numerous cracks penetrating entire thickness of the wall and extending from floor to ceiling iv failure to support structural loads between floor and roof systems v extensive fire damage creating hazardous conditions vi numerous cracks not penetrating entire thickness of wall vii deteriorating material over large areas large holes loose or missing material over large area viii sagging of a limited area ix fire damage affecting basic structural elements eg studs columns etc over a large area x termite infestation over large areas xi improper size or spacing of basic supporting members 4 chimneys and all flue and vent attachments thereto a chimneys and all flue and vent attachments thereto shall be maintained structurally sound free from defects and so maintained as to capably perform at all times the functions for which they were designed chimneys flues gas vents or other draftproducing equipment shall provide for uninterrupted passage for smoke or combustible gases to the outside b examples of defects include 1 substantial leaning or out of plumb 2 combustible material in direct contact with or in dangerous proximity to chimney 3 loose or missing material missing cap or broken flue lining over extensive area 4 cracks and holes over extensive area 5 chimney should extend above the highest point of the roof approximate two to three feet minimum 6 spalling open joints or other unsafe or hazardous conditions over most of the vertical length 7 tilting leaning or other footing failure 5 exterior porches landings balconies stairs and fire escapes a exterior porches landings balconies stairs and fire escapes shall be provided with banisters or railings properly designed and maintained to minimize the hazard of falling and the same shall be kept structurally sound in good repair and free from defects b examples of defects include 1 deterioration over an extensive area 2 loose or missing material over an extensive area 3 cracks and holes over an extensive area 4 extreme weakness due to fire damage or wear 5 lack of adequate support 6 sagging of treads or stringers 7 inadequate headroom headroom should be continuously clear six foot eight inch main six foot four inch service 8 improper tread and riser size treads and risers should be consistent all the way upstairs 9 improper construction improper size members or lack of footage under posts 6 appearance of buildings secondary structures or the exterior of premises buildings secondary structures exterior of the premises areas exposed to public view and the condition of all buildings truss b the roof structure as a system should be capable of supporting the required roof loads without indication of sag or deflection a crack warp or buckle in any member of the structural system are faults or defects also holes leaks corrosion or rotting of structural members of the system are faults critical joints between the exterior wall and the roof system should be protected by flashing should be capable of supporting floor loads without indications of sag or deflection the floor structure should provide bracing and act as a structural tie which keeps the walls in their vertical plane in addition the joist of the floor structure should provide the necessary support for the finished surface of the ceilings in the room below any cracking warping or buckling of any member of the floor structure is a fault rotting or corrosion of any member of the floor structure shall also be considered a fault b examples of floor defects include 1 deflection causing buckling of interior ceiling over an extensive area including water damage cracked material and broken missing or loose lath 9 exterior curtain walls a exterior curtain walls are those walls which are not part of a buildings structural supporting system exterior curtain walls do not support the floors or the roof  but rather their primary function is to enclose the building protect the structure from deterioration due to the elements and prevent the entrance of moisture or seasonal cold air or hot air exterior curtain walls are often the sections between columns or piers separated by floors on multistory buildings exterior curtain walls shall be kept free of any defects b examples of exterior curtain wall defects include 1 deterioration of parapets or coping over an extensive area 2 corrosion of large areas of metal exterior curtain wall 3 failure of curtain wall glass and framing 4 extensive cracks buckling or spalling of concrete masonry or ceramic exterior curtain walls 5 windows within exterior curtain wall sections 10 nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions a nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions are generally provided to partitions should also provide a suitable base surface for decorative finish nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions shall be kept free of any defects b examples of nonbearing wall and ceiling interior wall and partition defects include 1 walls or partitions out of plumb 2 bowing or bulging of an entire wall 3 extreme deterioration affecting major structural members over an of sag or deflection excessive sloping  broken treads or risers  and cracks warping or buckling of the supporting structure shall be considered defects interior stairs shall be kept free of all defects b examples of interior stair defects include 1 deterioration over an extensive area 2 loose or missing material over an extensive area 3 cracks and holes over an extensive area 4 extreme weakness due to fire damage or wear 5 lack of adequate support 6 sagging of treads or stringers 7 inadequate headroom headroom should be continuously clear six feet eight inches for main and six feet four inches for service 8 improper tread and riser size treads and risers should be consistent all the way upstairs 9 springing or inadequately sized or spaced stringers 10 wood stair platforms or landscapinglawnsweeds 1 landscaping a premises with landscaping hedges and bushes shall be kept trimmed and from becoming overgrown and unsightly where exposed to public view where the same constitute a blighting factor to adjoining propertyies 2 lawnsweeds a allowing in excess of six inches 1 it is unlawful for any person to permit suffer or allow any lawns thistles weeds brush or undergrowth or other vegetation of any kind whatsoever to be remain or grow to a height above six inches from the ground upon any lots parcels or tracts of land within the city 2 it shall be the duty of any person owning leasing or controlling any such lots tracts or parcels of land within the city to cause the undergrowth to be removed therefrom before the undergrowth reaches the heights of six inches  provided that this provision shall not apply to trees flowers or cultivated plants b notice to remove to be given by the building department 1 whenever it comes to the notice of the building department that any lot parcel or tract of land within the city is in violation of this article it shall be the duty of the building department to notify the landowner of the property by registered letter at the landowners last known address 2 the building department may also serve notice of the violation by attaching to any structure on the lot parcel or tract a statement of the violation in such cases the building department shall also notify the landowner by registered letter of the violation and of the notice attached to the structure on the lot parcel or tract 3 the landowner shall have three days to remove the vegetation upon receipt of the building departments registered letter c repeat offenders 1 anyone committing a second offence of this section within the same calendar year will receive a citation including a $2500 fine along with the three day notice to remove the growth d action by the building department on failure to act 1 upon the failure of the landowner to remove the vegetation within the specified time the building department shall send notice to appear in whiting city court the notice shall be sent by registered letter 2 upon notice to appear in whiting city court the landowner may be fines pursuant to section 111 for failure to remove the vegetation within the specified time and additional fines may be assessed for each additional day the vegetation has not been removed 3 upon failure to remove the vegetation within a mandated time period the whiting city court may ask the building department to remove the vegetation with the cost passed on to the landowner e assessment and collection of costs 1 the building department shall keep an accurate and itemized record of the amount of time and labor required to remove the vegetation from each lot tract or parcel of land upon completion of such work the board of public works and safety shall certify the cost of the removal which shall be entered upon the tax duplicate kept by law against such lots tracts or parcels of land from which the vegetation was removed 2 the city clerktreasurer must make a certified statement of the actual cost incurred by the city in the removal the statement must be delivered to the owner of the property by registered mail and the owners shall pay the amount to the clerktreasurer if the landowner fails to pay the amount within ten days after receiving the statement a certified copy of the statement of costs shall be filed in the office of the auditor of the county the auditor shall place the amount claimed on the tax duplicate against the property affected by the work and the amount shall be collected as taxes are collected and shall be disbursed to the general fund of the city d mechanical systems 1 the functions of the mechanics in any building are unlike the functions of structural components therefore defects are dissimilar and each defect requires an appropriate description mechanical systems shall be kept free of defects 2 examples of mechanical defects include a lack of a mechanical system applies when a particular building system does not exist in a building located within the city b inadequate service is the inability of a building system to adequately perform its intended function in relation to the demands placed upon it this would include such things as 1 a heating system which cannot supply sufficient heat to all parts of a structure 2 an electrical system which cannot supply sufficient voltage to operate all electrical appliances on the system 3 a plumbing system which cannot supply proper pressure or drain without backup c obsolescence in the building system means it can no longer efficiently perform the function for which it was originally designed d missing parts applies when essential parts are found to be missing in a building system such as a pressure gauge on a boiler insulators in an electrical system fire brick in a heating plant etc e leaking or seepage is the failure of a part of a building system to contain its contents such as a leaking water pipe or connection or a heating duct containing numerous holes f exposure of surfaces of an element of a building system which could result in a weather or fire safety hazard including bare electrical wires noninsulated hot water or steam pipes an exposed fire box etc g poor distribution of the electrical and heating systems exists when there is an inadequate number of electrical outlets or heating vents in rooms or spaces to provide proper distribution of the supply often electrical circuits are overloaded with too many receptacles on too few circuits while other circuits are connected to a limited number of outlets h improper connections of one element of a building system to another resulting in a loss of operating efficiency in the building system or fire or safety hazards which may include leaky pipe connections faulty electrical connections resulting in power loss loose fitting heating duct connections etc i deteriorating and physical decadence or decomposition of parts of a building system or an entire system may include rusting of flues and ducts in a heating system corrosion of pipes in the plumbing system a cracked or crumbling fire wall in a heating plant or frayed insulation on electric wires e electrical 1 all wiring is to be of the proper size installed to meet code requirements with insulating materials in good condition all connections should be properly secured to the structural system 2 there should be a proper disconnect switch for total cutoff of the system with proper leadin connection to meter and disconnect 3 each room should have electrical outlets and base plugs sufficient to provide adequate lighting and power sources for an appliances normal everyday use proper wiring should be provided for these outlets and plugs 4 residential dwelling units should have 100amp service with a minimum of 15amp fuses for each circuit 5 nonresidential buildings should be provided with electric service and electrical installations adequate to meet the needs of the facility and the code requirements 6 there should be a special circuit for oil or gas burners with a separate remote shutoff switch switches should be in operating condition 7 examples of electrical defects include a below minimum 30wire 60ampere service to a structure b knob and tube wiring below minimum code standards c extensive wear in the knob and tube wiring and does not meet minimum specifications d extensive use of nonmetallic sheathed cable and armored cable administrative provisions 1 issuance of complaints whenever it is alleged that any building is in violation of any of the provisions of section 4193 such that the building is unfit for human habitation occupancy or use that the continuation of any condition constitutes a defect fault or nuisance with the meaning of this division or presents a blighting condition harmful to the health and safety of the occupants of the building and the general public of the city the building commissioner or authorized official shall if upon preliminary investigation be determined that a basis for such circumstances exist issue and cause to be served notification of either a violation notice in accordance with section 2351 et seq or notice of a municipal ordinance violation in accordance with the provisions of this section upon the operators owners andor parties of interest stating the charges or violations and the necessary required action relative to the property in question 2 notice and orders a service generally complaints orders and notices issued by the building commissioner or his designee in connection with this division shall be served to the operators owners andor parties of interest by 1 sending a copy of the order or notice by first class mail to the residence place of business or employment of the person to be notified  or 2 delivering a copy of the order or notice personally to the person to be notified  or 3 leaving a copy of the order or notice at the property which is the subject of the violation notice or order b orders requiring action any order requiring action issued by the building commissioner or his designee must contain the following 1 the name of the person as the operator or owner to whom the order is issued 2 the legal description or the commonly known address of the property in violation of this division 3 the action that the order requires 4 the period of time in which the action is required to be accomplished with such period measured from the time when the notice of the order is given 5 a statement briefly indicating what action can be taken by the building commissioner if the order is not complied with within a stated period of time 6 a statement of the requirement to meet with the building commissioner or his designee within 30 days to discuss compliance seek clarification or additional time to comply with the order 7 the name address and telephone number of the building commissioner or the designee issuing the order 3 orders process a meeting with the building commissioner 1 the operators owners andor parties of interest shall schedule a meeting with the building commissioner within 30 days upon receipt of the building commissioners written communication to discuss the notice or order seek clarification or request additional time in which to comply with the order a meeting with the building commissioner or his designee does not stay the time period stated for compliance with the order failure to meet with the building commissioner or his designee during the designated time period shall be deemed as a failure to comply 2 results of the meeting at the conclusion of the meeting between the building commissioner and the operators owners andor parties of interest the building commissioner shall make written findings to the parties involved to i act on the order within the time specified by the building commissioner the building commissioner may grant a specific time period of up to 60 days to complete the order depending on the circumstances of each case the building commissioner may issue a written schedule of work to be accomplished if there are multiple violations in the order ii modify the original order and grant a specific time period of up to 60 days to act on the modified order iii rescind the original order 3 if the operators owners andor parties of interest fail to satisfy the terms of the order within the time designated by the building commissioner or his designee the order status shall be deemed as a failure to comply 4 if the operators owners andor parties of interest to whom the order was issued disagree with the building commissioners order they will have the right to appeal the order before the whiting city the party appealing the building commissioners determination shall notify the building commissioner or his designee of the date to appear before the whiting city for the appeal the date of appeal before the whiting city shall be filed within 30 days of receipt of the building commissioners final determination or the right to appeal is waived 5 the operators owners andor parties of interest shall be given the right to file an answer to all orders given by the building commissioner to appear in person to have legal representation present and to provide any relevant data andor testimony on the date scheduled by the whiting city  the building commissioner or his designee shall be present on the date the orders are brought before whiting city if heshe has been so notified by the appealing party b application of unsafe building procedures 1 if after the allotted time period mandated by the building commissioner the building commissioner determines that the property under consideration is unfit for human habitation or occupancy or use or such property has deteriorated to the level such that the property would be considered property subject to the unsafe building law as codified in of this chapter the building commissioner shall state in writing his findings of fact in support for such determination 2 under such circumstances all provisions of the unsafe building law as codified under of this chapter would then be applied to the property at issue 4 failure to comply a if the operators owners andor parties of interest in question fail to discuss the order with the building commissioner or his designee during the designated 30 day time period then such parties are deemed in violation of this division b if the operators owners andor parties of interest of the property in question after having been duly notified pursuant to the terms of this division fail to satisfy the building commissioners order such parties are deemed in violation of this division c upon a determination by the building commissioner or his designee that a failure to comply exists the building commissioner or his designee shall file an action with the whiting city to seek the imposition of fines and costs for failure to comply with the order the building commissioner shall notify the operators owners
